Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the theory behind remote sensing (e.g.: satellite image properties, different satellites/instruments, electromagnetic properties) and how to acquire, manipulate, and georeference satellite data in the first half of the course. The second half of the course is learning how to apply this processed data. I learned about change detection, vegetation monitoring, atmosphere/clouds, GPS, Field Surveys, ocean monitoring. We used ENVI for the majority of the project.
Solid ability to use satellite imagery for practical scientific analysis; knowledge of different types of satellites, sensors, data, data products, and applications.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: comprehensive, great course instructors/TAs, interesting content, interesting guest lecturers, very practical skill to have, learn transferable skills/knowledge in the the environmental field
Weaknesses: 1) having to go to ESC in a regular year to use the computer seems very inconvenient (keep the remote access option if possible); 2) the data acquisition and image pre-processes steps were skimmed over in one lecture--I think if there was a demo or slides that were more detailed on exactly how to perform radiometric/atmospheric correction then it'd be a lot less confusing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the virtual lab structure that they used.

Recorded lectures were a success! I attended lectures live most of the time but during very busy weeks, I prioritized other things and it was great being able to go back and watch lectures. In a regular year, all professors should make this a given--to have recorded lectures--if professors truly cared about the students' learning rather than something like always being in class. Besides being able to efficiently accomplish work due to recorded lectures, I was also able to re-watch lectures that I had attended to prepare for tests and finish a lab. I definitely would not have learned as much in this class if things weren't recorded--because re-watching things filled in the gaps. The remote access for the computers were a great success as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if you would like an introduction to remote sensing and think it could be useful to your research/future career.

Yes! If you are a little bit interested in remote sensing, then I would recommend that you take it! You learned theory in the first half of the course which can be boring and confusing at times (but also interesting). Then the real fun comes in the second half when you learn how to apply this knowledge to analyze satellite data. I'd emphasize this is more of a remote sensing course than a GIS course because you work more to pre-process and manipulate the satellite images than you do making visualizations. If you have no idea how to apply this in your work after Yale, this may not be the right class for you--but maybe you'll find a new passion after taking this course!

Absolutely, this course is essential and super useful for using satellite imagery in almost any natural sciences analysis of the Earth's surface (and doing your own project on it). Also, Natalie is fantastic in her support of the course in every lecture, with technical issues, and feedback for student projects. Additionally, the guest lecturers were all great and added fantastic perspective and breadth to the course material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture twice a week and lab once a week that was done individually or partially live seminar style.
Live lecture, recorded lecture, labs, course project
Live virtual lecture that was also recorded
